Check Independence of Observations - Gold Standard

Source: R/assumptions.R
check_independence.Rd

Provides comprehensive guidance and testing for the independence assumption. While true independence is primarily a design issue, this function helps you: (1) Think through your study design, (2) Detect potential violations, (3) Test for autocorrelation in time series or sequential data, and (4) Get actionable recommendations for violations.

Independence violations are among the most serious assumption violations because they directly inflate Type I error (false positives). This function provides extensive educational support for beginners.

Usage

check_independence(
  data = NULL,
  data_structure = "cross-sectional survey",
  is_independent = TRUE,
  id_var = NULL,
  time_var = NULL,
  clustering_note = NULL
)

Arguments

data

Numeric vector of residuals or raw data (optional). If provided, will test for autocorrelation. If NULL, provides design-based guidance only.

data_structure

Character. Description of your data collection design. Options: "cross-sectional survey" (default), "repeated measures", "time series", "clustered", "matched pairs", "panel data", "other".

is_independent

Logical. Do you believe observations are independent based on your study design? Default TRUE.

id_var

Optional vector of participant/cluster IDs for detecting repeated observations.

time_var

Optional vector indicating time order for autocorrelation testing.

clustering_note

Optional character string with additional context about data structure (e.g., "students nested within 12 classrooms").

Value

An S3 object of class "assumption_check" containing:

  • test: Type of assessment performed

  • assumption: "Independence of Observations"

  • assumption_met: Logical. TRUE if independent (based on design + tests)

  • data_structure: Your specified data structure

  • has_autocorrelation: Logical or NA (if tested)

  • autocorrelation: Lag-1 autocorrelation coefficient (if tested)

  • durbin_watson: Durbin-Watson statistic (if tested)

  • n_unique_ids: Number of unique IDs (if id_var provided)

  • n_obs: Total observations

  • avg_obs_per_id: Average observations per ID (if applicable)

  • interpretation: One-sentence summary

  • recommendation: Actionable next steps

  • publication_text: APA 7 formatted text

  • verbose_explanation: Educational explanation

  • design_checklist: Questions to assess independence

  • visual_guide: How to diagnose independence violations

Details

**What is the independence assumption?**

Independence means each observation is unrelated to other observations. One person's response doesn't influence another's response (beyond random chance).

**Common violations:** - Repeated measures (same person multiple times) - Time series (today depends on yesterday) - Clusters (students in same class, customers in same store) - Matched pairs or siblings - Social networks (friends influence friends)

**How to check:** 1. Think about study design (primary method) 2. Provide data to test for autocorrelation 3. Provide ID variable to detect repeated measures

Examples

# Example 1: Design-based check (independent)
check_independence(data_structure = "cross-sectional survey",
                   is_independent = TRUE)

#> PUBLICATION-READY TEXT:
#>   The data were collected using a cross-sectional survey design, ensuring

#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> 
#>   WHAT IS INDEPENDENCE OF OBSERVATIONS?
#>   
#>   Independence of observations is one of the most important assumptions in
#>   statistics. It means each data point represents a unique individual or unit,
#>   and one participant's response doesn't influence another's response (beyond
#>   random chance).
#>   
#>   Think of it this way: If you know Person A's score, does that tell you
#>   anything about Person B's score beyond what you'd expect by chance? If not,
#>   they're independent.
#>   
#>   YOUR STUDY DESIGN:
#>   
#>   Design type: cross-sectional survey
#>   
#>   Based on your design, the observations are independent. This is excellent!
#>   You can proceed with standard statistical analyses without special
#>   corrections.
#>   
#>   WHY THIS MATTERS:
#>   
#>   When independence is met: • Standard errors are correctly estimated •
#>   P-values are accurate • Confidence intervals have proper coverage • You can
#>   use all standard statistical tests
#>   
#>   If independence were violated (it's not in your case): • Standard errors
#>   would be TOO SMALL • P-values would be TOO SMALL (inflated Type I error) •
#>   You'd get false positives
#>   
#>   COMMON VIOLATIONS TO WATCH FOR (in future studies):
#>   
#>   • Repeated measures: Same person measured multiple times • Time series:
#>   Today's value depends on yesterday's • Clustered data: Students within
#>   classrooms, customers within stores • Matched pairs: Siblings, couples, or
#>   intentionally paired units • Social networks: Friends influencing friends
#>   
#>   If you had violations, you'd need: • Repeated measures ANOVA (for repeated
#>   data) • Mixed effects models (for clustered/nested data) • Time series
#>   methods (for sequential data) • Paired tests (for matched data)
#> 
#> 
#> ========================================================================
#> INDEPENDENCE CHECKLIST: Questions to Ask About Your Study
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> Work through these questions to assess independence:
#> 
#> 1. DATA COLLECTION DESIGN:
#>    □ Did each participant contribute only ONE observation?
#>    □ Were participants randomly sampled from the population?
#>    □ Could one participant's response influence another's?
#> 
#> 2. REPEATED MEASURES:
#>    □ Is anyone measured more than once?
#>    □ Are there pre-test and post-test measurements?
#>    □ Do you have multiple items per person?
#>    → If YES to any: Use repeated measures methods
#> 
#> 3. CLUSTERING/NESTING:
#>    □ Are participants grouped (classrooms, stores, teams)?
#>    □ Do participants within groups share experiences?
#>    □ Were participants recruited as groups?
#>    → If YES to any: Use mixed effects models
#> 
#> 4. TIME/SEQUENCE:
#>    □ Are observations ordered in time?
#>    □ Could today's value depend on yesterday's?
#>    □ Is there a trend over time?
#>    → If YES to any: Use time series methods or include time effects
#> 
#> 5. MATCHING/PAIRING:
#>    □ Are observations intentionally paired (couples, siblings)?
#>    □ Did you match participants on characteristics?
#>    □ Are there natural pairs in your data?
#>    → If YES to any: Use paired tests
#> 
#> 6. SOCIAL NETWORK:
#>    □ Do participants know each other?
#>    □ Could social influence affect responses?
#>    □ Did you sample from interconnected groups?
#>    → If YES to any: Use network analysis methods
#> 
#> DECISION RULE:
#> 
#> If you answered YES to ANY question above, your data likely violates independence.
#> You MUST use specialized methods that account for the dependence structure.
#> 
#> When in doubt: Consult a statistician or use mixed effects models (they're robust).
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> ========================================================================
#> VISUAL DIAGNOSTICS: How to Detect Independence Violations
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> Independence violations can sometimes be detected visually:
#> 
#> --- AUTOCORRELATION PLOT (For Time Series Data) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   # Using residuals from a model
#>   model <- lm(outcome ~ predictors, data = your_data)
#>   res <- residuals(model)
#>   
#>   # Autocorrelation function
#>   acf(res, main = "Autocorrelation of Residuals")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Spikes within blue dashed lines = No autocorrelation ✓
#>   • Spikes outside blue lines = Autocorrelation detected
#>   • Lag 1 spike = Adjacent observations correlated
#>   • Pattern of spikes = Systematic dependence
#> 
#> --- RESIDUALS VS ORDER PLOT ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   model <- lm(outcome ~ predictors, data = your_data)
#>   plot(residuals(model), type = "l",
#>        main = "Residuals Over Time",
#>        ylab = "Residuals")
#>   abline(h = 0, col = "red")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Random scatter around zero = Independent ✓
#>   • Patterns or trends = Dependence
#>   • Clustering of similar values = Autocorrelation
#>   • Runs above/below zero = Non-independence
#> 
#> --- CLUSTER/GROUP COMPARISON ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   boxplot(outcome ~ cluster_id, data = your_data,
#>           main = "Outcome by Cluster")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Different median levels across clusters = Clustering effect
#>   • Wide variation between clusters = Non-independence
#>   → Need mixed effects model with random intercepts
#> 
#> --- DURBIN-WATSON TEST (Formal Test) ---
#> 
#> Run in R:
#>   library(lmtest)
#>   dwtest(your_model)
#> 
#> PRACTICAL ADVICE:
#> 
#>   • If unsure: Assume dependence and use robust methods
#>   • Mixed effects models are rarely wrong (even if independence holds)
#>   • Standard methods with dependence are often wrong
#>   • Better to be conservative than to get false positives
#> ========================================================================
#> 

# Example 2: Design-based check (violation)
check_independence(data_structure = "repeated measures",
                   is_independent = FALSE,
                   clustering_note = "3 measurements per participant")
#>

#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===

#> 
#> Test Used: Independence Assessment 
#> Result: FAIL ASSUMPTION VIOLATED 
#> 
#> INTERPRETATION:
#>   The independence assumption is VIOLATED based on study design (repeated
#>   measures).
#> 
#> 
#> RECOMMENDATION:
#>   REQUIRED: Use repeated measures ANOVA or mixed effects model.
#>   
#>   DO NOT use standard t-tests, ANOVA, or regression - they assume independence
#>   and will give you incorrect results (inflated Type I error, false positives).
#>   
#>   IN R: # Option 1: Repeated measures ANOVA (ezANOVA package) library(ez)
#>   ezANOVA(data = your_data, dv = outcome, wid = id, within = time)
#>   
#>   # Option 2: Mixed effects model (lme4 package) library(lme4) lmer(outcome ~
#>   predictor + (1 | id), data = your_data)
#> 
#> 
#> PUBLICATION-READY TEXT:
#>   The data structure (repeated measures) involved non-independent observations.
#>   Accordingly, repeated measures ANOVA or mixed effects model was employed to
#>   account for dependencies.
#> 
#> 
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---

#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> DETAILED EXPLANATION (for learning and context):
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> 
#>   CRITICAL: INDEPENDENCE ASSUMPTION VIOLATED
#>   
#>   Independence of observations is one of the MOST important assumptions in
#>   statistics. Your study design (repeated measures) creates dependencies in the
#>   data.
#>   
#>   WHAT THIS MEANS:
#>   
#>   Some observations are related to each other beyond random chance. This could
#>   be: • Same people measured multiple times (repeated measures) • Observations
#>   nested within groups (students in classrooms) • Sequential/time-ordered data
#>   (autocorrelation) • Matched or paired observations
#>   
#>   Your context: 3 measurements per participant
#>   
#>   WHY THIS IS CRITICAL:
#>   
#>   When you ignore dependence, standard tests (t-test, ANOVA, regression): ✖
#>   Underestimate standard errors (make them TOO SMALL) ✖ Produce p-values that
#>   are TOO SMALL ✖ Inflate Type I error rate (false positives) ✖ Give you
#>   'significant' results that are actually wrong
#>   
#>   Example: If your true Type I error is 20% instead of 5%, you'll get false
#>   positives 4 times more often than you think!
#>   
#>   WHAT YOU MUST DO:
#>   
#>   Use specialized methods that account for dependence: repeated measures ANOVA
#>   or mixed effects model.
#>   
#>   These methods: ✓ Correctly estimate standard errors ✓ Give accurate p-values
#>   ✓ Account for correlation structure ✓ Are widely accepted in publications
#>   
#>   DO NOT: ✖ Use standard t-tests ✖ Use standard ANOVA ✖ Use standard linear
#>   regression ✖ Ignore the dependence
#>   
#>   These will give you WRONG results.
#> 
#> 
#> ========================================================================
#> INDEPENDENCE CHECKLIST: Questions to Ask About Your Study
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> Work through these questions to assess independence:
#> 
#> 1. DATA COLLECTION DESIGN:
#>    □ Did each participant contribute only ONE observation?
#>    □ Were participants randomly sampled from the population?
#>    □ Could one participant's response influence another's?
#> 
#> 2. REPEATED MEASURES:
#>    □ Is anyone measured more than once?
#>    □ Are there pre-test and post-test measurements?
#>    □ Do you have multiple items per person?
#>    → If YES to any: Use repeated measures methods
#> 
#> 3. CLUSTERING/NESTING:
#>    □ Are participants grouped (classrooms, stores, teams)?
#>    □ Do participants within groups share experiences?
#>    □ Were participants recruited as groups?
#>    → If YES to any: Use mixed effects models
#> 
#> 4. TIME/SEQUENCE:
#>    □ Are observations ordered in time?
#>    □ Could today's value depend on yesterday's?
#>    □ Is there a trend over time?
#>    → If YES to any: Use time series methods or include time effects
#> 
#> 5. MATCHING/PAIRING:
#>    □ Are observations intentionally paired (couples, siblings)?
#>    □ Did you match participants on characteristics?
#>    □ Are there natural pairs in your data?
#>    → If YES to any: Use paired tests
#> 
#> 6. SOCIAL NETWORK:
#>    □ Do participants know each other?
#>    □ Could social influence affect responses?
#>    □ Did you sample from interconnected groups?
#>    → If YES to any: Use network analysis methods
#> 
#> DECISION RULE:
#> 
#> If you answered YES to ANY question above, your data likely violates independence.
#> You MUST use specialized methods that account for the dependence structure.
#> 
#> When in doubt: Consult a statistician or use mixed effects models (they're robust).
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> ========================================================================
#> VISUAL DIAGNOSTICS: How to Detect Independence Violations
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> Independence violations can sometimes be detected visually:
#> 
#> --- AUTOCORRELATION PLOT (For Time Series Data) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   # Using residuals from a model
#>   model <- lm(outcome ~ predictors, data = your_data)
#>   res <- residuals(model)
#>   
#>   # Autocorrelation function
#>   acf(res, main = "Autocorrelation of Residuals")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Spikes within blue dashed lines = No autocorrelation ✓
#>   • Spikes outside blue lines = Autocorrelation detected
#>   • Lag 1 spike = Adjacent observations correlated
#>   • Pattern of spikes = Systematic dependence
#> 
#> --- RESIDUALS VS ORDER PLOT ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   model <- lm(outcome ~ predictors, data = your_data)
#>   plot(residuals(model), type = "l",
#>        main = "Residuals Over Time",
#>        ylab = "Residuals")
#>   abline(h = 0, col = "red")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Random scatter around zero = Independent ✓
#>   • Patterns or trends = Dependence
#>   • Clustering of similar values = Autocorrelation
#>   • Runs above/below zero = Non-independence
#> 
#> --- CLUSTER/GROUP COMPARISON ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   boxplot(outcome ~ cluster_id, data = your_data,
#>           main = "Outcome by Cluster")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Different median levels across clusters = Clustering effect
#>   • Wide variation between clusters = Non-independence
#>   → Need mixed effects model with random intercepts
#> 
#> --- DURBIN-WATSON TEST (Formal Test) ---
#> 
#> Run in R:
#>   library(lmtest)
#>   dwtest(your_model)
#> 
#> PRACTICAL ADVICE:
#> 
#>   • If unsure: Assume dependence and use robust methods
#>   • Mixed effects models are rarely wrong (even if independence holds)
#>   • Standard methods with dependence are often wrong
#>   • Better to be conservative than to get false positives
#> ========================================================================
#> 

# Example 3: Test for autocorrelation
set.seed(123)
residuals <- arima.sim(model = list(ar = 0.7), n = 100)
check_independence(data = residuals,
                   data_structure = "time series")
#> Warning: Autocorrelation detected in data
#> ! Lag-1 correlation = 0.719
#> ℹ This suggests observations are NOT independent
#> → Consider: Is there a time or sequence component?
#>

#> STATISTICAL ASSUMPTION CHECK: Independence of Observations
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===
#> ===

#> Test Used: Independence Assessment 
#> Result: FAIL ASSUMPTION VIOLATED 
#> 
#> INTERPRETATION:
#>   The independence assumption is VIOLATED based on autocorrelation testing (r =
#>   0.719) and study design (time series).
#> 
#> 
#> RECOMMENDATION:
#>   REQUIRED: Use time series analysis (ARIMA, autocorrelation modeling).
#>   
#>   DO NOT use standard t-tests, ANOVA, or regression - they assume independence
#>   and will give you incorrect results (inflated Type I error, false positives).
#>   
#>   IN R: # ARIMA model library(forecast) auto.arima(your_time_series)
#> 
#> 
#> PUBLICATION-READY TEXT:
#>   The data structure (time series) involved non-independent observations
#>   (autocorrelation r = 0.719). Accordingly, time series analysis (ARIMA,
#>   autocorrelation modeling) was employed to account for dependencies.
#> 
#> 
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---

#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> DETAILED EXPLANATION (for learning and context):
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> ---
#> 
#>   CRITICAL: INDEPENDENCE ASSUMPTION VIOLATED
#>   
#>   Independence of observations is one of the MOST important assumptions in
#>   statistics. Your study design (time series) creates dependencies in the data.
#>   
#>   WHAT THIS MEANS:
#>   
#>   Some observations are related to each other beyond random chance. This could
#>   be: • Same people measured multiple times (repeated measures) • Observations
#>   nested within groups (students in classrooms) • Sequential/time-ordered data
#>   (autocorrelation) • Matched or paired observations
#>   
#>   AUTOCORRELATION DETECTED: Lag-1 correlation: 0.719 Durbin-Watson: 0.561 →
#>   This indicates TIME-SERIES DEPENDENCE
#>   
#>   WHY THIS IS CRITICAL:
#>   
#>   When you ignore dependence, standard tests (t-test, ANOVA, regression): ✖
#>   Underestimate standard errors (make them TOO SMALL) ✖ Produce p-values that
#>   are TOO SMALL ✖ Inflate Type I error rate (false positives) ✖ Give you
#>   'significant' results that are actually wrong
#>   
#>   Example: If your true Type I error is 20% instead of 5%, you'll get false
#>   positives 4 times more often than you think!
#>   
#>   WHAT YOU MUST DO:
#>   
#>   Use specialized methods that account for dependence: time series analysis
#>   (ARIMA, autocorrelation modeling).
#>   
#>   These methods: ✓ Correctly estimate standard errors ✓ Give accurate p-values
#>   ✓ Account for correlation structure ✓ Are widely accepted in publications
#>   
#>   DO NOT: ✖ Use standard t-tests ✖ Use standard ANOVA ✖ Use standard linear
#>   regression ✖ Ignore the dependence
#>   
#>   These will give you WRONG results.
#> 
#> 
#> ========================================================================
#> INDEPENDENCE CHECKLIST: Questions to Ask About Your Study
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> Work through these questions to assess independence:
#> 
#> 1. DATA COLLECTION DESIGN:
#>    □ Did each participant contribute only ONE observation?
#>    □ Were participants randomly sampled from the population?
#>    □ Could one participant's response influence another's?
#> 
#> 2. REPEATED MEASURES:
#>    □ Is anyone measured more than once?
#>    □ Are there pre-test and post-test measurements?
#>    □ Do you have multiple items per person?
#>    → If YES to any: Use repeated measures methods
#> 
#> 3. CLUSTERING/NESTING:
#>    □ Are participants grouped (classrooms, stores, teams)?
#>    □ Do participants within groups share experiences?
#>    □ Were participants recruited as groups?
#>    → If YES to any: Use mixed effects models
#> 
#> 4. TIME/SEQUENCE:
#>    □ Are observations ordered in time?
#>    □ Could today's value depend on yesterday's?
#>    □ Is there a trend over time?
#>    → If YES to any: Use time series methods or include time effects
#> 
#> 5. MATCHING/PAIRING:
#>    □ Are observations intentionally paired (couples, siblings)?
#>    □ Did you match participants on characteristics?
#>    □ Are there natural pairs in your data?
#>    → If YES to any: Use paired tests
#> 
#> 6. SOCIAL NETWORK:
#>    □ Do participants know each other?
#>    □ Could social influence affect responses?
#>    □ Did you sample from interconnected groups?
#>    → If YES to any: Use network analysis methods
#> 
#> DECISION RULE:
#> 
#> If you answered YES to ANY question above, your data likely violates independence.
#> You MUST use specialized methods that account for the dependence structure.
#> 
#> When in doubt: Consult a statistician or use mixed effects models (they're robust).
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> ========================================================================
#> VISUAL DIAGNOSTICS: How to Detect Independence Violations
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> Independence violations can sometimes be detected visually:
#> 
#> --- AUTOCORRELATION PLOT (For Time Series Data) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   # Using residuals from a model
#>   model <- lm(outcome ~ predictors, data = your_data)
#>   res <- residuals(model)
#>   
#>   # Autocorrelation function
#>   acf(res, main = "Autocorrelation of Residuals")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Spikes within blue dashed lines = No autocorrelation ✓
#>   • Spikes outside blue lines = Autocorrelation detected
#>   • Lag 1 spike = Adjacent observations correlated
#>   • Pattern of spikes = Systematic dependence
#> 
#> --- RESIDUALS VS ORDER PLOT ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   model <- lm(outcome ~ predictors, data = your_data)
#>   plot(residuals(model), type = "l",
#>        main = "Residuals Over Time",
#>        ylab = "Residuals")
#>   abline(h = 0, col = "red")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Random scatter around zero = Independent ✓
#>   • Patterns or trends = Dependence
#>   • Clustering of similar values = Autocorrelation
#>   • Runs above/below zero = Non-independence
#> 
#> --- CLUSTER/GROUP COMPARISON ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   boxplot(outcome ~ cluster_id, data = your_data,
#>           main = "Outcome by Cluster")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Different median levels across clusters = Clustering effect
#>   • Wide variation between clusters = Non-independence
#>   → Need mixed effects model with random intercepts
#> 
#> --- DURBIN-WATSON TEST (Formal Test) ---
#> 
#> YOUR DURBIN-WATSON STATISTIC: 0.561
#> 
#> Interpretation:
#>   • DW ≈ 2.0: No autocorrelation ✓
#>   • DW < 1.5: Positive autocorrelation (successive values similar)
#>   • DW > 2.5: Negative autocorrelation (successive values alternate)
#> 
#> Your value suggests POSITIVE AUTOCORRELATION - observations are dependent
#> 
#> PRACTICAL ADVICE:
#> 
#>   • If unsure: Assume dependence and use robust methods
#>   • Mixed effects models are rarely wrong (even if independence holds)
#>   • Standard methods with dependence are often wrong
#>   • Better to be conservative than to get false positives
#> ========================================================================
#> 

# Example 4: Detect repeated measures
set.seed(123)
data_vals <- rnorm(150)
ids <- rep(1:50, each = 3)  # 3 obs per person
check_independence(data = data_vals,
                   id_var = ids,
                   data_structure = "repeated measures")

#> Test Used: Independence Assessment 
#> Result: FAIL ASSUMPTION VIOLATED 
#> 
#> INTERPRETATION:
#>   The independence assumption is VIOLATED based on study design (repeated
#>   measures (detected)).
#> 
#> 
#> RECOMMENDATION:
#>   REQUIRED: Use repeated measures ANOVA or mixed effects model.
#>   
#>   DO NOT use standard t-tests, ANOVA, or regression - they assume independence
#>   and will give you incorrect results (inflated Type I error, false positives).
#>   
#>   YOUR DATA: 150 observations from 50 unique units (avg 3 obs per unit).
#>   
#>   IN R: # Option 1: Repeated measures ANOVA (ezANOVA package) library(ez)
#>   ezANOVA(data = your_data, dv = outcome, wid = id, within = time)
#>   
#>   # Option 2: Mixed effects model (lme4 package) library(lme4) lmer(outcome ~
#>   predictor + (1 | id), data = your_data)
#> 
#> 
#> PUBLICATION-READY TEXT:
#>   The data structure (repeated measures (detected)) involved non-independent
#>   observations (autocorrelation r = -0.015). Accordingly, repeated measures
#>   ANOVA or mixed effects model was employed to account for dependencies.

#>   statistics. Your study design (repeated measures (detected)) creates
#>   dependencies in the data.
#>   
#>   WHAT THIS MEANS:
#>   
#>   Some observations are related to each other beyond random chance. This could
#>   be: • Same people measured multiple times (repeated measures) • Observations
#>   nested within groups (students in classrooms) • Sequential/time-ordered data
#>   (autocorrelation) • Matched or paired observations
#>   
#>   Your context: Detected 150 observations from 50 unique IDs (average 3 obs per
#>   ID)
#>   
#>   DETECTED STRUCTURE: Total observations: 150 Unique units: 50 Avg observations
#>   per unit: 3 → This indicates REPEATED MEASURES or CLUSTERING
#>   
#>   AUTOCORRELATION DETECTED: Lag-1 correlation: -0.015 Durbin-Watson: 2.013 →
#>   This indicates TIME-SERIES DEPENDENCE
#>   
#>   WHY THIS IS CRITICAL:
#>   
#>   When you ignore dependence, standard tests (t-test, ANOVA, regression): ✖
#>   Underestimate standard errors (make them TOO SMALL) ✖ Produce p-values that
#>   are TOO SMALL ✖ Inflate Type I error rate (false positives) ✖ Give you
#>   'significant' results that are actually wrong
#>   
#>   Example: If your true Type I error is 20% instead of 5%, you'll get false
#>   positives 4 times more often than you think!
#>   
#>   WHAT YOU MUST DO:
#>   
#>   Use specialized methods that account for dependence: repeated measures ANOVA
#>   or mixed effects model.
#>   
#>   These methods: ✓ Correctly estimate standard errors ✓ Give accurate p-values
#>   ✓ Account for correlation structure ✓ Are widely accepted in publications
#>   
#>   DO NOT: ✖ Use standard t-tests ✖ Use standard ANOVA ✖ Use standard linear
#>   regression ✖ Ignore the dependence
#>   
#>   These will give you WRONG results.
#>

#> INDEPENDENCE CHECKLIST: Questions to Ask About Your Study
#> ========================================================================

#> Work through these questions to assess independence:
#> 
#> 1. DATA COLLECTION DESIGN:
#>    □ Did each participant contribute only ONE observation?
#>    □ Were participants randomly sampled from the population?
#>    □ Could one participant's response influence another's?
#> 
#> 2. REPEATED MEASURES:
#>    □ Is anyone measured more than once?
#>    □ Are there pre-test and post-test measurements?
#>    □ Do you have multiple items per person?
#>    → If YES to any: Use repeated measures methods
#> 
#> 3. CLUSTERING/NESTING:
#>    □ Are participants grouped (classrooms, stores, teams)?
#>    □ Do participants within groups share experiences?
#>    □ Were participants recruited as groups?
#>    → If YES to any: Use mixed effects models
#> 
#> 4. TIME/SEQUENCE:
#>    □ Are observations ordered in time?
#>    □ Could today's value depend on yesterday's?
#>    □ Is there a trend over time?
#>    → If YES to any: Use time series methods or include time effects
#> 
#> 5. MATCHING/PAIRING:
#>    □ Are observations intentionally paired (couples, siblings)?
#>    □ Did you match participants on characteristics?
#>    □ Are there natural pairs in your data?
#>    → If YES to any: Use paired tests
#> 
#> 6. SOCIAL NETWORK:
#>    □ Do participants know each other?

#>    □ Did you sample from interconnected groups?

#> You MUST use specialized methods that account for the dependence structure.

#> ========================================================================

#> ========================================================================
#> VISUAL DIAGNOSTICS: How to Detect Independence Violations
#> ========================================================================
#> 
#> Independence violations can sometimes be detected visually:
#> 
#> --- AUTOCORRELATION PLOT (For Time Series Data) ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   # Using residuals from a model
#>   model <- lm(outcome ~ predictors, data = your_data)
#>   res <- residuals(model)
#>   
#>   # Autocorrelation function
#>   acf(res, main = "Autocorrelation of Residuals")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Spikes within blue dashed lines = No autocorrelation ✓

#>   • Pattern of spikes = Systematic dependence
#> 
#> --- RESIDUALS VS ORDER PLOT ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   model <- lm(outcome ~ predictors, data = your_data)
#>   plot(residuals(model), type = "l",
#>        main = "Residuals Over Time",
#>        ylab = "Residuals")
#>   abline(h = 0, col = "red")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Random scatter around zero = Independent ✓
#>   • Patterns or trends = Dependence
#>   • Clustering of similar values = Autocorrelation
#>   • Runs above/below zero = Non-independence
#> 
#> --- CLUSTER/GROUP COMPARISON ---
#> 
#> Create the plot:
#>   boxplot(outcome ~ cluster_id, data = your_data,
#>           main = "Outcome by Cluster")
#> 
#> How to interpret:
#>   • Different median levels across clusters = Clustering effect
#>   • Wide variation between clusters = Non-independence
#>   → Need mixed effects model with random intercepts
#> 
#> --- DURBIN-WATSON TEST (Formal Test) ---
#> 
#> YOUR DURBIN-WATSON STATISTIC: 2.013
#> 
#> Interpretation:
#>   • DW ≈ 2.0: No autocorrelation ✓
#>   • DW < 1.5: Positive autocorrelation (successive values similar)
#>   • DW > 2.5: Negative autocorrelation (successive values alternate)
#> 
#> Your value suggests NO STRONG AUTOCORRELATION - independence is plausible
#> 
#> PRACTICAL ADVICE:
#> 
#>   • If unsure: Assume dependence and use robust methods
#>   • Mixed effects models are rarely wrong (even if independence holds)
#>   • Standard methods with dependence are often wrong
#>   • Better to be conservative than to get false positives
